'''Hans Hassle''', born 1959, is a Swedish entrepreneur and businessman who focuses on [[corporate social responsibility]]. He runs the management consultancy company evolution? AB and serves as the General Secretary of [[Plantagon]] International Association.<ref>http://plantagon.com/</ref>
==Biography== Hans Hassle worked as a freelance journalist between 1981 and 1986 focusing on travel journalism. He, amongst other things, was portraying [[indigenous peoples]] from places such as [[Tibet]], [[Indonesia]], and [[New Zealand]]. In 1986 he had a story published in ''[[People Magazine]]'' from his time on the Indonesian island [[Siberut]], where he lived with the animist [[Mentawai people|Mentawei]] tribe.
Hassle has been working with [[social entrepreneurship]], [[corporate social responsibility]] (CSR), and brand management since 1986. He founded the Swedish communication agency Vision and Reality Communication NetWork AB in 1986 and spent 15 years as its CEO. In 1989 Hassle developed the notion of [[Event Marketing]] and together with [[Procter & Gamble]] used the facade of the [[Ericsson Globe]] to draw attention to the new product [[Ariel (detergent)|Ariel]].
In 1989, Hassle, together with former head of the department of culture in Rättvik, Åsa Nyman, and former CEO of Draggängarnas limestone quarry, Margareta Dellefors, established the first working group for the development of outdoor area [[Dalhalla]] in Rättvik.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dalarna.se/sv/Nyheter/Dalhalla/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130417020958/http://www.dalarna.se/sv/Nyheter/Dalhalla/ |archivedate=2013-04-17 |df= }}</ref>
Hassle was in 2001 appointed member of the Central Ethical Review Board<ref>http://www.epn.se/en/start/startpage/</ref> at the [[Karolinska Institute]] in Stockholm by the [[Swedish government]].
Hassle has been a member of the steering committee of the Swedish [[Geopark]] project Meteorum since 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rattvik.se/meteorum |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105210540/http://www.rattvik.se/meteorum |archivedate=2012-11-05 |df= }}</ref>
Since 2008 Hans Hassle serves as the CEO and General Secretary of [[Plantagon]]. The company is founded by Hassle and the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] nation [[Onondaga Nation]].<ref>http://www.onondaganation.org/</ref> Hans was the first European citizen to ever be appointed CEO and General Secretary of a company owned by a Native American nation and run outside of the [[United States]].<ref>[http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2010/08/rejecting_casinos_onondagas_in.html Article on Plantagon], The Post-Standard, Syracuse, August 29, 2010</ref>
==Corporate Social Responsibility==
Since 1986, Hassle has been working with [[social entrepreneurship]] and [[corporate social responsibility]] (CSR). In 1992 he protected the brand [[Corporate Citizenship]].<ref>http://www.prv.se/en The Swedish Patent and Registration Office</ref>
In 2004, Hassle co-authored together Christina Carsten, professor at the Stockholm Center for Organizational Research,<ref>http://www.score.su.se/english/</ref> the [[United Nations Global Compact|Global Compact]] Research Report Sweden<ref>http://www.unglobalcompact.org/docs/news_events/9.1_news_archives/2005_02_08/gc_res_rep_swe.pdf</ref> which is a report monitoring attitudes towards the [[UN]]'s recommendations on "Good Corporate Citizenship".
Hassle has developed a new business model called the Companization <ref>http://www.plantagon.com/governance/companization</ref>- a hybrid of a non-profit association and a for-profit company that incorporates moral values into an otherwise economic forum by implementing the [[Earth Charter]] and the [[United Nations Global Compact]] into the articles of association of the company.
== International Recognition==
In 2012, Hans Hassle became an official member of the [[World Entrepreneurship Forum]] and joined the Forum’s Think Tank as one of 88 members.<ref>http://www.world-entrepreneurship-forum.com/Communities/Members</ref>
Hassle was in 2010 and 2011 nominated Sustainable Leader of the Year by the Swedish Association of Environmental Managers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nmc.a.se/en/home.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130910212903/http://www.nmc.a.se/en/home.html |archivedate=2013-09-10 |df= }}</ref> In 2012, he was awarded CEO of the Year, Sweden<ref>http://www.europeanceo.com/ceo-of-the-year-2012/</ref> by European CEO<ref>http://www.europeanceo.com/</ref> as well as received the World Finance 100<ref>http://worldfinance100.com/</ref> award in 2012.
==Family==
Hassle is married to Karin Hassle, glass artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hassle.st/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704134957/http://hassle.st/ |archivedate=2013-07-04 |df= }}</ref> Together they have two children.
==Bibliography==
Co-author of the Global Compact Research Report Sweden <ref>[http://www.unglobalcompact.org/docs/news_events/9.1_news_archives/2005_02_08/gc_res_rep_swe.pdf Global Compact Research Report Sweden]</ref> published by [[UN Global Compact]] in 2004.<ref>http://www.unglobalcompact.org/</ref>
Author of the book "Business as Usual is over" ({{ISBN|978-91-980170-0-7}}), published in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plantagon.com/article/business-as-usual-is-over-den-roda-kapitalisten---pocket |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120925012311/http://plantagon.com/article/business-as-usual-is-over-den-roda-kapitalisten---pocket |archivedate=2012-09-25 |df= }}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} Most textbooks date the establishment of the "Publicity Bureau" in 1900 as the start of the modern [[public relations]] (PR) profession. Of course, there were many early forms of public influence and communications management in history. Basil Clarke is considered the founder of the public relations profession in Britain with his establishment of Editorial Services in 1924. Academic Noel Turnball points out that systematic PR was employed in Britain first by religious evangelicals and Victorian reformers, especially opponents of slavery. In each case the early promoters focused on their particular movement and were not for hire more generally.
[[Propaganda]] was used by both sides to rally domestic support and demonize enemies during the First World War. PR activists entered the private sector in the 1920s. Public relations became established first in the US by [[Ivy Lee]] or [[Edward Bernays]], then spread internationally. Many American companies with PR departments spread the practice to Europe after 1948 when they created European subsidiaries as a result of the [[Marshall plan]].
The second half of the twentieth century was the professional development building era of public relations. Trade associations, PR news magazines, international PR agencies, and academic principles for the profession were established. In the early 2000s, press release services began offering social media press releases. [[The Cluetrain Manifesto]], which predicted the impact of social media in 1999, was controversial in its time, but by 2006, the effect of social media and new internet technologies became broadly accepted.
==Ancient origins== [[File:Gustave dore crusades dandolo preaching the crusade.jpg|thumb|right|An artistic depiction of a preacher promoting the crusades|200px]] Although the term "public relations" was not yet developed,<ref name="GrunewaldPetrausch2008"/> academics like [[James E. Grunig]] and [[Scott Cutlip]] identified early forms of public influence and communications management in ancient civilizations.<ref name="DozierGrunig2013">{{cite book|author1=David M. Dozier|author2=Larissa A. Grunig|author3=James E. Grunig|title=Manager's Guide to Excellence in Public Relations and Communication Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VReOAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA41|date=October 18, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-68832-4|page=41}}</ref>{{rp|41}} According to [[Edward Bernays]], one of the pioneers of PR, "The three main elements of public relations are practically as old as society: informing people, persuading people, or integrating people with people."<ref>{{citation|title="Mini-Me" History|first=Don|last=Bates|year=2002|accessdate=February 5, 2014|url=http://engine.koduleht.net/templates/kajatampere/files/mdl_files.php/HistoryofPublicRelationInstitute.pdf}}</ref><ref name="barbara"/><ref name="Bernays2013"/> Scott Cutlip said historic events have been defined as PR retrospectively, "a decision with which many may quarrel."<ref name="antec">{{cite book|last=Cutlip|first=Scott|title=Public Relations History: From the 17th to the 20th Century. The antecedents|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum|year=1995|isbn=0-8058-1779-4}}</ref>
A clay tablet found in ancient Iraq that promoted more advanced agricultural techniques is sometimes considered the first known example of public relations.<ref name="GrunewaldPetrausch2008"/><ref name="FreitagStokes2009">{{cite book|author1=Alan R. Freitag|author2=Ashli Quesinberry Stokes|title=Global Public Relations: Spanning Borders, Spanning Cultures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPrOtG3lv0QC&pg=PA18|date=January 13, 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-06129-7|page=18}}</ref><ref name="BarkerAngelopulo2005">{{cite book|author1=Rachel Barker|author2=George Charles Angelopulo|title=Integrated Organisational Communication|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D7rkS-Q-mYUC&pg=PA194|date=August 1, 2005|publisher=Juta and Company Ltd|isbn=978-0-7021-6664-8|page=194}}</ref> Babylonian, Egyptian and Persian leaders created pyramids, obelisks and statues to promote their divine right to lead. Additionally, claims of magic or religious authority were used to persuade the public of a king or pharaoh's right to rule.<ref name="Bernays2013"/>
Ancient Greek cities produced sophisticated rhetoric, as analyzed by [[Isocrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]].<ref name="Marsh Jr.2001">{{cite journal|last1=Marsh Jr.|first1=Charles W.|title=Public Relations Ethics: Contrasting Models from the Rhetorics of Plato, Aristotle, and Isocrates|journal=Journal of Mass Media Ethics|volume=16|issue=2-3|year=2001|pages=78–98|issn=0890-0523|doi=10.1080/08900523.2001.9679606}}</ref><ref name="Marsh2013">{{cite book|first=Charles|last=Marsh|title=Classical Rhetoric and Modern Public Relations: An Isocratean Model|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OJsAOcUHIlYC&pg=PA4|date=April 26, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-24263-2|pages=4-}}</ref> In Greece there were advocates for hire called "[[Sophism|sophists]]". [[Plato]] and others said sophists were dishonest and misled the public, while the book "''Public Relations as Communication Management''" said they were "largely an ethical lot" that "used the principles of persuasive communication."<ref name="managementt"/> In Egypt court advisers consulted pharaohs to speak honestly<ref name="Smith2013">{{cite book|first=Ron|last=Smith|title=Public Relations: The Basics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5WxtAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA38|date=August 15, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-08967-2}}</ref>{{RP|38}} and [[scribe]]s documented a [[pharaoh]]'s deeds.<ref name="autogenerated1971">{{cite book|title=Life in Ancient Egypt, 1894|first=Adolf|last=Erman|author2=H. M. Tirrand|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-TqnHMN920UC|date=August 1, 2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-7660-7}}</ref> In Rome [[Julius Caesar]] wrote the first campaign biography promoting his military successes. He also commissioned newsletters and poems to support his political position.<ref name="GrunewaldPetrausch2008"/><ref name="Smith2013"/>{{RP|39}} In medieval Europe, craftsmen organized into guilds that managed their collective reputation. In England, [[Lord Chancellors]] acted as mediators between rulers and subjects.<ref name="cutliptwo">{{cite book|last=Cutlip|first=Scott|title=The Unseen Power: A History of Public Relations|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates|volume=|edition=|year=1994|location=|pages=|language=|url=|doi=|id=|isbn=0-8058-1464-7}}</ref><ref name="lt">{{citation|url=http://faculty.buffalostate.edu/smithrd/PR/history.htm|title=Public Relations History|publisher=Buffalo State University|date=Fall 2004|first=Ron|last=Smith|accessdate=February 7, 2013 }}</ref>
[[Pope Urban II]]'s recruitment for the [[crusades]] is also sometimes referred to as a public relations effort.<ref name="GrunewaldPetrausch2008">{{cite book|author1=Donald Grunewald|author2=Robert J. Petrausch|author3=Giri Dua|title=Public Relations: A Primer for Business Executives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XT4LbwcjgAYC&pg=PA1|accessdate=February 9, 2013|date=November 25, 2008|publisher=iUniverse|isbn=978-1-4401-0165-6|page=1}}</ref><ref name="lt"/><ref name="L'Etang2012">{{cite book|first=Jacquie|last=L'Etang|title=Public Relations: Critical Debates and Contemporary Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ti2I3OKoYMC&pg=PA35|accessdate=February 10, 2013|date=December 6, 2012|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-8058-4617-1|page=35}}</ref> [[Pope Gregory XV]] founded the term "propaganda" when he created ''Congregatio de Propaganda'' ("congregation for propagating the faith"), which used trained missionaries to spread Christianity.<ref name="JowettO'Donnell2011"/> The term did not carry negative connotations until it was associated with government publicity around [[World War II]].<ref name="cutliptwo"/><ref name="JowettO'Donnell2011">{{cite book|author1=Garth S. Jowett|author2=Victoria O'Donnell|title=Propaganda & Persuasion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o8tXNRjSW60C&pg=PT105|accessdate=February 11, 2013|date=April 12, 2011|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-1-4129-7782-1|page=105}}</ref><ref name="Plessis2001">{{cite book|author=DF du Plessis|title=Introduction to Public Relations and Advertising|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dU2Yz3u9lMoC|accessdate=July 27, 2013|date=January 1, 2001|publisher=Juta and Company Ltd|isbn=978-0-7021-5557-4}}</ref> In the early 1200s, the [[Magna Carta]] was created as a result of [[Stephen Langton]] lobbying English barons to insist [[John, King of England|King John]] recognize the authority of the church.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite book|first=Ron|last=Smith|title=Public Relations: The Basics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5WxtAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA40|date=August 15, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-08967-2|page=40}}</ref>
==Antecedents== [[File:New England's First Fruits plaque, Harvard University - IMG 8969.JPG|thumb|left|A plaque from Harvard quoting a passage from the fundraising pamphlet, New England's First Fruits]] Explorers like [[Ferdinand Magellan|Magellan]], [[Christopher Columbus|Columbus]] and [[kelvin kasiwulaya and Talent Gonsalo]] used exaggerated claims of grandeur to entice settlers to come to the [[New World]].<ref name="autogenerated2004"/> For example, in 1598, a desolate swampy area of Virginia was described by Captain [[Arthur Barlowe]] as follows: "The soil is the most plentiful, sweet, fruitful and wholesome of all the world."<ref name="barbara">{{cite book|author=Barbara Diggs-Brown|title=Strategic Public Relations: Audience Focused Practice, 1st ed.: An Audience-focused Approach|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7c0ycySng4YC|date=May 15, 2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-534-63706-4}}</ref><ref name="antec"/> When colonists wrote back to Europe about the hardships of colonizing [[Virginia]], including the death toll caused by conflicts with Indians, pamphlets with anonymous authors were circulated to reassure potential settlers and rebuke criticisms.<ref name="antec"/>
The first newsletter and the first daily newspaper were founded in Germany in 1609 and 1615 respectively.<ref name="Bernays2013"/> [[Cardinal Richelieu]] of France had pamphlets made that supported his policies and attacked his political opposition. The government also created a publicity bureau called Information and Propaganda and a weekly newspaper originally controlled by the French government, [[La Gazette|The Gazette]].<ref name="french"/><ref name="SrirameshVercic2012" /> In the mid-1600s both sides of the [[English Civil War]] conflict used pamphlets to attack or defend the monarchy respectively.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Politicians_and_Pamphleteers.html?id=xOPDzpuiN1wC|title=Politicians and Pamphleteers: Propaganda During the English Civil Wars and Interregnum|first=Jason|last= Peacey|year=2004|publisher=Ashgate Publishing}}</ref> Poet [[John Milton]] wrote anonymous pamphlets advocating for ideas such as liberalizing divorce, the establishment of a republic and the importance of [[free speech]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KTPFPD5VfTsC|title=John Milton: A Biography|first=Neil |last=Forsyth|year=2008|publisher=Lion Books|pages=69–79}}</ref> A then-anonymous pamphlet in 1738 by [[Maria Theresa]] of the [[Austrian Empire]] was influential in criticizing the [[freemasons]] and advocating for an alliance between the British, Dutch and Austrian governments.<ref name="Pennsylvania1991">{{cite book|author=Margaret C. Jacob Professor of History and Sociology of Science University of Pennsylvania|title=Living the Enlightenment : Freemasonry and Politics in Eighteenth-Century Europe: Freemasonry and Politics in Eighteenth-Century Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w9y1pF-Na3UC&pg=PA29|date=November 11, 1991|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-976279-8|pages=29–30}}</ref>
In 1641, [[Harvard University]] sent three preachers to England to raise money for missionary activities among the Indians. To support the fund-raising, the University produced one of the earliest fund-raising brochures, ''New England's First Fruits''.<ref name="cutliptwo"/><ref name="autogenerated2006">{{cite news|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2006/6/7/calibrating-the-public-relations-machine-the/|last=Troianovski|first=Anton|date=June 7, 2006|title=Calibrating the Public Relations Machine|publisher=The Harvard Crimson|accessdate=February 17, 2013}}</ref> An early version of the press release was used when King's College (now [[Columbia University]]), sent out an announcement of its 1758 graduation ceremonies and several newspapers printed the information.<ref name="autogenerated2004"/> [[Princeton University|Princeton]] was the first university to make it a routine practice of supplying newspapers with information about activities at the college.<ref name="autogenerated2004"/>
[[File:BLAKE10.JPG|thumb|200px|right|A medallion from 1787 promoting the abolitionist cause]]According to Noel Turnball, a professor from [[RMIT University]], more systematic forms of PR began as the public started organizing for social and political movements.<ref name="Turnbull">{{citation|url=http://noelturnbull.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/How-PR-works-but-often-doesnt.pdf |title=How PR Works, but often doesn't |first=Noel |last=Turnbull |isbn=978-0-646-53625-5 |year=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225080735/http://noelturnbull.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/How-PR-works-but-often-doesnt.pdf |archivedate=December 25, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0674050002|title=The Association British Extra Parliamentary Political Organization, 1769–1793|author=Eugene Charlton Black|year=1963|publisher=Harvard University Press|page=279}}</ref> The [[Society for Effecting the Abolition of the Slave Trade]] was established in England in 1787.<ref name="HortonHorton2013">{{cite book|author1=James Oliver Horton|author2=Lois E. Horton|author2-link=Lois Horton|title=Slavery And Public History: The Tough Stuff of American Memory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=acuWeOproyoC&pg=PT53|date=December 13, 2013|publisher=New Press|isbn=978-1-59558-744-2|page=53}}</ref> It published books, posters and hosted public lectures in England advocating against slavery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/people/williamwilberforce_1.shtml|title=William Wilberforce|publisher=BBC|accessdate=January 22, 2014|date=July 5, 2011}}</ref> Industries that relied on slavery attempted to persuade the middle-class that it was necessary and that slaves had humane living conditions.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CBjqG6eHpNsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Bury+the+Chains:+Prophets+and+Rebels+in+the+Fight+to+Free+an+Empire%27s+Slaves&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZmBpU7LdDoG28gHxooHQCg&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Bury%20the%20Chains%3A%20Prophets%20and%20Rebels%20in%20the%20Fight%20to%20Free%20an%20Empire's%20Slaves&f=false|title=Bury the Chains: Prophets and Rebels in the Fight to Free an Empire's Slaves|first=Adam|last=Hochschild|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|year=2005|page=160}}</ref> The [[Slave Trade]] was abolished in [[Slave Trade Act 1807|1807]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Leo|last=D'Anjou|title=Social Movements and Cultural Change: The First Abolition Campaign|year=1996|publisher=Aldine de Gruyter|isbn= 978-0-202-30522-6|page=198}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=British History - Abolition of the Slave Trade 1807|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/abolition/africans_in_art_gallery_02.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=April 11, 2009|quote=The Wedgwood medallion was the most famous image of a black person in all of 18th-century art.}}</ref> In the US, the movement to abolish slavery began in 1833 with the establishment of the [[American Anti-Slavery Society]],<ref name="barbara"/> using tactics adopted from the British abolitionist movement. According to [[Edward Bernays]], the US abolitionist movement used "every available device of communication, appeal and action," such as petitions, pamphlets, political lobbying, local societies, and boycotts. The South responded by defending slavery on the basis of economics, religion and the constitution. In some cases propaganda promoting the abolition of slavery was forbidden in The South and abolitionists were killed or jailed.<ref name="Bernays2013">{{cite book|author=Edward L. Bernays|title=Public Relations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0NpSb5nmn5sC&pg=PT23|date=July 29, 2013|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-8982-6|page=23}}</ref> Public relations also played a role in abolitionist movements in France, Australia and in Europe.<ref name="Smith2013"/>
The [[Boston Tea Party]] has been called a "public relations event" or [[pseudo event]] in that it was a staged event intended to influence the public.<ref name="managementt"/><ref name="autogenerated2006"/> Pamphlets such as ''[[Common Sense (pamphlet)|Common Sense]]'' (1775–76) and ''[[The American Crisis]]'' (1776 to 1783) were used to spread anti-British propaganda in the United States, as well as the slogan "taxation without representation is tyranny." After the revolution was won, disagreements broke out regarding the [[United States Constitution]]. Supporters of the constitution sent letters now called the [[Federalist Papers]] to major news outlets, which helped persuade the public to support the constitution.<ref name="barbara"/><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite book|author=D F du Plessis|title=Introduction to Public Relations and Advertising|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dU2Yz3u9lMoC|date=January 1, 2001|publisher=Juta and Company Ltd|isbn=978-0-7021-5557-4}}</ref> Exaggerated stories of [[Davy Crocket]] and the [[California Gold Rush]] were used to persuade the public to fight the [[American-Mexican War|war against Mexico]] and to migrate west in the U.S. respectively.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{citation|last=Smith|first=Ron|date=Fall 2004|title=Public Relations History|publisher=Buffalo State University|accessdate=February 7, 2013|url=http://faculty.buffalostate.edu/smithrd/PR/history.htm}}</ref>
Author Marvin Olasky said public relations in the 1800s was spontaneous and de-centralized.<ref name="latest"/> In the 1820s, Americans wanted to disprove the perspective of French aristocrats that the American democracy run by "the mob" had "no sense of history, no sense of gratitude to those who had served it, and no sense of the meaning of 'virtue'". To combat this perception, French aristocrat [[Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette|Marquis de Lafayette]], who helped fund the [[American Revolution]], was invited to a tour of the United States. Each community he visited created a committee to welcome him and promote his visit.<ref name="latest"/> In the mid-1800s [[P. T. Barnum]] founded the American Museum and the Barnum and Bailey Circus.<ref name="arendaiu">{{cite book|title=Public Relations - Theory|date=Fall 2009|publisher=Mr. Rajkumar Mascreen, Manipal Universal Learning Pvt. Ltd|location=Manipal|pages=2–3}}</ref> He became well known for publicizing his circus using manipulative techniques.<ref name="managementt"/><ref name="Plessis2001"/><ref name="Heath2006"/> For example, he announced that his museum would exhibit a 161-year-old woman, who had been Washington's nurse, then produced an elderly woman and a forged birth certificate.<ref name="arendaiu"/>
In the 1860s, the major railway companies building the [[First Transcontinental Railroad|Transcontinental Railroad]] ([[Central Pacific Railroad]] in Sacramento, California, and the [[Union Pacific Railroad]] in New York City) engaged in "sophisticated and systematic corporate public relations" in order to raise $125 million needed to construct the 1,776-mile-long railroad. To raise the money, the companies needed to maintain "an image attractive to potential bond buyers, [and maintain relationships] with members of Congress, the California state legislature, and federal regulators; with workers and potential workers; and with journalists."<ref>Leland K. Wood, "When the Locomotive Puffs: Corporate Public Relations of the First Transcontinental Railroad Builders" (PhD dissertation, Journalism, Ohio State U. 2009) [https://etd.ohiolink.edu/ap/10?0::NO:10:P10_ETD_SUBID:61239 online] {{ISBN|1244078166}}.</ref>
Early [[environmentalism|environmental campaigning groups]] like the [[Environmental Protection UK|Coal Abatement Society]] and the [[Congo Reform Association]] were formed in the late 1800s.<ref name="Turnbull" /> In the late 1800s many of the now-standard practices of media relations, such as conducting interviews and press conferences emerged.<ref name="RulerVerčič2004"/> Industrial firms began to promote their public image. The German steel and armaments company [[Krupp]] created the first corporate press department in 1870 to write articles, brochures and other communications advertising the firm.<ref name="RulerVerčič2004">{{cite book|author1=Betteke Van Ruler|author2=Dejan Verčič|title=Public Relations and Communication Management in Europe: A Nation-by-Nation Introduction to Public Relations Theory and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AAkj51GOor0C&pg=PA161|accessdate=July 25, 2013|year=2004|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-017612-4|page=161}}</ref> The first US corporate PR department was established in 1889 by [[Westinghouse Corporation]].<ref name="autogenerated53">Reddi (2010). Effective Public Relations And Media Strategy. PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd. pp. 53. Retrieved February 11, 2013.</ref> "The first public relations department was created by the inventor and industrialist George Westinghouse in 1889 when he hired two men to publicize his pet project,alternating current (AC) electricity."<ref name="autogenerated53"/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Lawrence, A. T., & Weber, J.|title=Business and society: Stakeholders, ethics, public policy|date=2014|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=New York, NY|isbn=9780078029479|pages=429|edition=14th}}</ref> The first appearance of the term "public relations" was in the ''1897 Year Book of Railway Literature''.<ref>"1897 American Journalism's Exceptional Year." 1897 American Journalism's Exceptional Year. N.p., n.d. Web. April 22, 2013.</ref>
==Origins as a profession== The book ''Today's Public Relations: An Introduction'' says that, although experts disagree on public relations' origins, many identify the early 1900s as its beginning as a paid profession.<ref name="Heath2006"/> According to Barbara Diggs-Brown, an academic with the [[American University School of Communication]], the PR field anchors its work in historical events in order to improve its perceived validity, but it didn't begin as a professional field until around 1900.<ref name="barbara" /> [[Scott Cutlip]] said, "we somewhat arbitrarily place the beginnings of the public relations vocation with the establishment of The Publicity Bureau in Boston in mid-1900." He explains that the origins of PR cannot be pinpointed to an exact date, because it developed over time through a series of events.<ref name="cutliptwo"/> Most textbooks on public relations say that it was first developed in the United States, before expanding globally;<ref name="L'Etang2004">{{cite book|first=Jacquie|last=L'Etang|title=Public Relations in Britain: A History of Professional Practice in the Twentieth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hEuTTo4lpTYC|accessdate=May 22, 2013|date=September 2, 2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-4106-1081-2}}</ref> however, Jacquie L'Etang, an academic from the United Kingdom, said it was developed in the UK and the US simultaneously.<ref name="L'Etang2004"/> Noel Turnball claims it began as a professional field in the 18th and 19th century with British evangelicals and Victorian reformers.<ref name="Turnbull"/> According to academic Betteke Van Ruler, PR activities didn't begin in [[Continental Europe]] as a professional field until the 1920s.<ref name="RulerVerčič2004" />
<s>According to academic [[Stuart Ewen]], most PR efforts in the US at the time were "damage control".<ref name="Ewen2008" /></s> According to Goldman, from around 1903 to 1909 "many newspapers and virtually all mass-circulation magazines featured detailed, indignant articles describing how some industry fleeced its stockholders, overcharged the public or corrupted politics." The public became abruptly more critical of big business.<ref name="twoway"/> The anti-corporate and pro-reform sentiment of the [[Progressive Era]] was reflected in newspapers, which were dramatically increasing in circulation as the cost of paper decreased.<ref name="Ewen2008">{{cite book|first=Stuart|last=Ewen|title=Pr!: A Social History of Spin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEcBIPpSBNsC|date=August 4, 2008|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-7867-2414-7}}</ref><ref name="jstor">{{Cite journal | last1 = Tedlow | first1 = Richard S. | last2 = | first2 = | year = 1976 | title = The National Association of Manufacturers and Public Relations during the New Deal | journal = The Business History Review | volume = 50 | issue = 1 | pages = 25–45 | publisher = | jstor = 3113573 | doi = 10.2307/3113573 | url = | format = | accessdate = }}</ref> Public relations was founded, in part, to defend corporate interests against sensational and hyper-critical news articles.<ref name="managementt"/><ref name="Ewen2008"/><ref name="jstor"/> It was also influential in promoting [[consumerism]] after the emergence of [[mass production]].<ref>{{cite AV media | people =Adam Curtis | title =The Century of the Self | medium =Documentary | publisher =BBC Four | location = | date =2002 | url =http://topdocumentaryfilms.com/the-century-of-the-self/ }}</ref>
===Early pioneers=== [[File:Ruins of Ludlow restored.jpg|thumb|right|The aftermath of the Ludlow Massacre]] The Publicity Bureau was the first PR agency and was founded by former Boston journalists, including [[Ivy Lee]].<ref name="barbara"/><ref name="Manning2004">{{cite book|author=Martin J. Manning|title=Historical Dictionary of American Propaganda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-JjwDPcOLQC|date=January 1, 2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-29605-5}}</ref> Ivy Lee is sometimes called the father of PR and was influential in establishing it as a professional practice. In 1906, Lee published a Declaration of Principles, which said that PR work should be done in the open, should be accurate and cover topics of public interest.<ref name="Plessis2001"/><ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite book |author= Barbara Diggs-Brown|title= Strategic Public Relations: An Audience-Centered Practice |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=7c0ycySng4YC&pg=PA40 |accessdate= March 27, 2013 |date=August 11, 2011 |publisher= Cengage Learning |isbn= 978-0-534-63706-4 |page=40 }}</ref><ref name="nyttwo">{{cite news |first=Timothy |last=O'Brien |date= Feb 13, 2005 |accessdate= March 16, 2013 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/13/business/yourmoney/13flak.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title= Spinning Frenzy: P.R.'s Bad Press |newspaper= The New York Times}}</ref> According to historian Eric Goldman, the declaration of principles marked the beginning of an emphasis on informing, rather than misleading, the public.<ref name="twoway">{{cite book | last =Goldman | first =Eric | title =Two-Way Street | publisher =Bellman Publishing Company | year =1948}}</ref> Ivy Lee is also credited with developing the modern [[press release]] and the "two-way-street" philosophy of both listening to and communicating with the public.<ref name="Levy2006"/> In 1906, Lee helped facilitate the Pennsylvania Railroad's first positive media coverage after inviting press to the scene of a railroad accident, despite objections from executives. At the time, secrecy about corporate operations was common practice.<ref name="twoway"/> Lee's work was often identified as spin or propaganda.<ref name="Diggs-Brown2011"/> In 1913 and 1914, the mining union was blaming the [[Ludlow Massacre]], where on-strike miners and their families were killed by state militia, on the Rockefeller family and their coal mining operation, The Colorado Fuel and Iron Company.<ref name="iyu">{{citation|title=Ivy Lee and the Rockefellers' response to the 1913–1914 Colorado Coal Strike|url=http://truty.org/PDFs/PR/%28PR%29IvyLeeRockerfeller&Ludlow.pdf|first=Kirk|last=Halllahan|publisher=Journal of Public Relations Research|year=2002}}</ref><ref name="iyu"/> On the Rockefeller family's behalf, Lee published bulletins called "Facts Concerning the Struggle in Colorado for Industrial Freedom," which contained false and misleading information.<ref name="Diggs-Brown2011"/><ref name="Rees2011">{{cite book|author=Jonathan H. Rees|title=Representation and Rebellion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8sDCZlq0nn4C&pg=PA15-IA3|accessdate=March 28, 2013|date=May 18, 2011|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4571-0984-3|page=15}}</ref><ref name="Rees2011"/> Lee warned that the Rockefellers were losing public support and developed a strategy that Junior followed to repair it. It was necessary for Junior to overcome his shyness, go personally to Colorado to meet with the miners and their families, inspect the conditions of the homes and the factories, attend social events, and especially to listen closely to the grievances. This was novel advice, and attracted widespread media attention, which opened the way to resolve the conflict, and present a more humanized versions of the Rockefellers.<ref>Robert L. Heath, ed.. ''Encyclopedia of public relations'' (2005) 1:485</ref> In response the labor press said Lee "twisted the facts" and called him a "paid liar," a "hired slanderer," and a "poisoner of public opinion."<ref name="Diggs-Brown2011"/> By 1917, Bethlehem Steel company announced it would start a publicity campaign against perceived errors about them. The [[Y.M.C.A.]] opened a new press secretary. AT&T and others also started their first publicity programs.<ref name="twoway"/>
[[Edward Bernays]], a nephew of [[Sigmund Freud]], is also sometimes referred to as the father of PR and the profession's first theorist for his work in the 1920s.<ref name="Ali2005">{{cite book|first=Moi|last=Ali|title=Public Relations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dAZN1dA9JhoC&pg=PA7|accessdate=May 21, 2013|date=October 30, 2005|publisher=HEINEMANN LIB|isbn=978-1-4034-7654-8|pages=7-}}</ref> He took the approach that audiences had to be carefully understood and persuaded to see things from the client's perspective.<ref name="nyttwo"/><ref name="Turow2011"/> He wrote the first textbook on PR and taught the first college course at [[New York University]] in 1923.<ref name="managementt"/> Bernays also first introduced the practice of using [[front groups]] in order to protect tobacco interests.<ref name="nyttwo"/><ref name="Turow2011">{{cite book|first=Joseph|last=Turow|title=Media Today: An Introduction to Mass Communication|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MZsSMKQZoYwC&pg=PA565|accessdate=March 16, 2013|date=September 22, 2011|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-136-86402-5|page=565}}</ref> In the 1930s he started the first vocational course in PR.<ref name="journal">Natasha Tobin, (2005), "[https://dx.doi.org/10.1108/13632540510621498 Can the professionalisation of the UK PR industry make it more trustworthy?]", Journal of Communication Management, Vol. 9 Iss: 1 pp. 56 – 64</ref> Bernays was influenced by Freud's theories about the subconscious.<ref name="Levy2006">{{cite book|author=Stuart M Levy|title=Public Relations & Integrated Communications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rHKplNphJ7MC&pg=PA2|accessdate=April 22, 2013|date=January 1, 2006|publisher=Lotus Press|isbn=978-81-8382-074-5|page=2}}</ref> He authored several books, including ''Crystallizing Public Opinion'' (1923), ''Propaganda'' (1928), and [[The Engineering of Consent]] (1947).<ref name="managementt"/><ref>{{cite book | last =Bernays | first =Edward | title =Crystallizing Public Opinion | publisher =Liveright Publishing Corporation | year =1923 | language = | url =http://sttpml.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/5369599-Crystallizing-Public-Opinion-Edward-Bernays.pdf}}</ref> He saw PR as an "applied social science" that uses insights from psychology, sociology, and other disciplines to scientifically manage and manipulate the thinking and behavior of an irrational and "herdlike" public.<ref name="Ali2005"/><ref name="RamptonStauber2002">{{cite book|author1=Sheldon Rampton|author2=John Stauber|title=Trust Us, We're Experts PA: How Industry Manipulates Science and Gambles with Your Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_OEPBt16JscC&pg=PT41|accessdate=May 21, 2013|date=January 14, 2002|publisher=Penguin Group US|isbn=978-1-101-14406-0|page=41}}</ref>
[[File:Kvinde-emancipation.gif|260px|thumb|left|Image showing woman smoking]]In 1929, Edward Bernays helped the [[Lucky Strike]] cigarette brand increase its sales among the female demographic.<ref name="Heath2006">{{cite book|first=Robert|last=Heath|title=Today's Public Relations: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-peK2-ceM4C|accessdate=July 27, 2013|year=2006|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-2635-5}}</ref> Research showed that women were reluctant to carry a pack of Lucky Strike cigarettes, because the brand's green color scheme clashed with popular fashion choices. Bernays persuaded fashion designers, charity events, interior designers and others to popularize the color green.<ref name="Heath2006"/> He also positioned cigarettes as [[Torches of Freedom]] that represent rebellion against the norms of a male-dominated society.<ref name="Diggs-Brown2011">{{cite book|author=Diggs-Brown|title=Strategic Public Relations: An Audience-focused Approach|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7c0ycySng4YC&pg=PA48|accessdate=May 21, 2013|date=August 11, 2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-534-63706-4|page=48}}</ref>
According to Ruth Edgett from [[Syracuse University]], Lee and Bernays both had "initial and spectacular successes in raising PR from the art of the snake oil salesman to the calling for a true communicator." However, "late in their careers, both Lee and Bernays took on clients with clearly reprehensible values, thus exposing themselves and their work to public criticism."<ref name="ruth">{{citation|title=Toward an Ethical Framework for Advocacy in Public Relations|url=http://truty.org/PDFs/PR/%28PR%29TowardAnEthicalFrameworkForAdvocacy.pdf|publisher=Journal of Public Relations|year=2002|first=Ruth|last=Edgett}}</ref> [[Walter Lippmann]] was also a contributor to early PR theory, for his work on the books ''Public Opinion'' (1922) and ''The Phantom Public'' (1925). He coined the term "manufacture of consent," which is based on the idea that the public's consent must be coaxed by experts to support a democratic society.<ref name="barbara"/>
Former journalist [[Basil Clarke]] is considered the founder of PR in the UK.<ref name="Oliver2004">{{cite book|first=Sandra|last=Oliver|title=A Handbook of Corporate Communication and Public Relations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zzHQxPT69dYC&pg=PA350|date=April 22, 2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-203-41495-8|pages=350-}}</ref><ref name="basil"/> He founded the UK's first PR agency, Editorial Services, in 1924.<ref name="L'Etang2004"/><ref name="basil">{{cite news|title=The Man who invented public relations|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2013/jun/06/marketingandpr-history|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Roy|last=Greenslade|date=June 6, 2013|accessdate=November 22, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Watson2012"/> He also authored the world's first code of ethics for the field in 1929.<ref>{{cite news|title=Basil Clarke at the Manchester Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/from-the-archive-blog/2013/jun/07/basil-clarke-public-relations-archive|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Richard|last=Nelsson|date=June 7, 2013|accessdate=July 25, 2013}}</ref> Clarke wrote that PR, "must look true and it must look complete and candid or its 'credit' is gone". He suggested that the selection of which facts are disseminated by PR campaigns could be used to persuade the public.<ref name="clarke">{{cite web|url=http://prstudies.com/2013/07/15/basil-clarke-past-and-present-of-pr/|title=Basil Clarke: past and present of PR|accessdate=December 24, 2013|first=Richard|last=Baily}}</ref> The longest established UK PR agency is Richmond Towers, founded by Suzanne Richmond and Marjorie Towers in 1930.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Who's Who In Press Publicity Printing|last=|first=|publisher=Cosmopolitan Press Ltd|year=1932|isbn=|location=London|pages=178}}</ref>
[[Arthur W. Page]] is sometimes considered to be the father of "corporate public relations" for his work with the [[American Telephone and Telegraph Company]] (AT&T) from 1927 to 1946.<ref name="barbara"/><ref name="Litwin2009">{{cite book|author=M. Larry Litwin|title=The Public Relations Practitioner's Playbook: A Synergized Approach to Effective Two-way Communication|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s7xzjZTEcpcC&pg=PA9|accessdate=July 25, 2013|year=2009|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=978-1-4389-9475-8|page=9}}</ref> The company was experiencing resistance from the public to its monopolization efforts.<ref name="john"/> In the early 1900s, AT&T had assessed that 90 percent of its press coverage was negative, which was reduced to 60 percent by changing its business practices and disseminating information to the press.<ref name="Watson2012">{{cite journal|last1=Watson|first1=Tom|title=The evolution of public relations measurement and evaluation|journal=Public Relations Review|volume=38|issue=3|year=2012|pages=390–398|issn=0363-8111|doi=10.1016/j.pubrev.2011.12.018}}</ref> According to business historian [[John Brooks (writer)|John Brooks]], Page positioned the company as a [[public utility]] and increased the public's appreciation for the its contributions to society.<ref name="john">{{cite book|first=John|last=Brooks|title=Telephone: the first hundred years|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H4NjAAAAIAAJ|year=1976|publisher=Harper & Row|isbn=978-0-06-010540-2}}</ref> On the other hand, Stuart Ewen writes that AT&T used its advertising dollars with newspapers to manipulate its coverage and had their PR team write feature stories imitating [[independent journalism]].<ref name="Ewen2008" />
===Early campaigns=== [[File:Empire Marketing Board poster.jpg|right|thumb|Empire Marketing Board poster.]] Edward Clarke and Bessie Tyler were influential in growing the [[Ku Klux Clan]] to four million members over three years using publicity techniques in the early 1920s.<ref name="Smith2013"/> In 1926 the [[Empire Marketing Board]] was formed by the British government in part to encourage a preference for goods produced in Britain. It folded in 1933 due to government cuts.<ref name=OU>{{cite web|last=Hack|first=Karl|title=Selling Empire: The Empire Marketing Board|url=http://www.open.edu/openlearn/history-the-arts/history/world-history/selling-empire-the-empire-marketing-board|work=OpenLearn|publisher=The Open University|accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> In 1932, a pamphlet "''The Projection of England''" advocated for the importance of England managing its reputation domestically and abroad.<ref name="L'Etang2004"/> The [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] was established in the UK in 1937.<ref name="L'Etang2004"/>
[[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]] and [[Woodrow Wilson]] were the first Presidents to emphasize the use of publicity.<ref name="twoway"/> In the 1930s Roosevelt used the media to promote [[The New Deal]] and to blame corporations for the country's economic problems. This led companies to recruit their own publicists to defend themselves.<ref name="cutliptwo"/> Roosevelt's anti-trust efforts led corporations to attempt to persuade the public and lawmakers "that bigger [corporations] was not necessarily more evil."<ref name="managementt"/> Wilson used the media to promote his government reform program, [[The New Freedom]].<ref name="twoway"/> He formed the [[Committee on Public Information]].<ref name="HeathCoombs2006">{{cite book|author1=Robert L. Heath|author2=W. Timothy Coombs|title=Today's Public Relations: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-peK2-ceM4C&pg=PA55|year=2006|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-2635-5|page=55}}</ref>
In the 1930s, the [[National Association of Manufacturers]] was one of the first to create a major campaign promoting capitalism and pro-business viewpoints.<ref>Burton St. John III, "Press Professionalization and Propaganda: The Rise of Journalistic Double-Mindedness, 1917–1941." Amherst, NY: Cambria Press, 2010; p. 12.</ref> It lobbied against unions, The New Deal and the 8-hour work-day. NAM tried mostly unsuccessfully to convince the public that the interests of the public were aligned with corporate interests and to create an association between commerce and democratic principles.<ref name="antec"/><ref name="Ewen2008"/><ref name="jstor"/> During the [[Second World War]], [[Coca-Cola]] promised that "every man in uniform gets a bottle of Coca-Cola for five cents, wherever he is and whatever it costs the company." The company persuaded politicians that it was crucial to the war-effort and was exempted from sugar rationing.<ref name="Pendergrast2000">{{cite book|first=Mark|last=Pendergrast| authorlink=Mark Pendergrast|title=For God, Country, and Coca-Cola: The Definitive History of the Great American Soft Drink and the Company That Makes It|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bSAChoqpnHUC&pg=PA249|accessdate=July 25, 2013|year=2000|publisher=BasicBooks|isbn=978-0-465-05468-8|page=249}}</ref> During the [[European Recovery Program]] PR became more established in Europe as US-based companies with PR departments created European subsidiaries.<ref name="french">{{citation|title=The History of Public Relations |url=http://www.globalalliancepr.org/website/sites/default/files/globalalliance/pr-landscape-france.pdf |accessdate=February 11, 2013 |first=Emily |last=Chinowth |date=July 2010 |publisher=Global Alliance for Public Relations and Communication Management |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120907030432/http://www.globalalliancepr.org/website/sites/default/files/globalalliance/pr-landscape-france.pdf |archivedate=September 7, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="Watson2012"/>
In 1938, amid concerns regarding dropping diamond prices and sales volume, [[De Beers]] and its advertising agency N.W. Ayers adopted a strategy to "strengthen the association in the public's mind of diamonds with romance," whereas "the larger and finer the diamond, the greater the expression of love." This became known as one of America's "lexicon of great campaigns" for successfully persuading the public to purchase expensive luxury items during a time of financial stress through [[psychological manipulation]]. It also led to the development of the slogan "A diamond is forever" in 1947 and was influential in how diamonds were marketed thereafter.<ref name="O'Rourke2007">{{cite book|author=James S. O'Rourke|title=The Business Communication Casebook: A Notre Dame Collection|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iuubbUJ8W7YC&pg=PA49|accessdate=July 25, 2013|date=January 2007|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-324-54509-8|page=49}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Have You Ever Tried to Sell a Diamond?|first=Edward|last=Epstein|date=February 1, 1982|accessdate=July 25, 2013|newspaper=The Atlantic|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1982/02/have-you-ever-tried-to-sell-a-diamond/304575/}}</ref> After World War I the first signs of public relations as a profession began in France and became more established through the [[Marshall Plan]].<ref name="french"/>
==Wartime propaganda==
===World War I=== [[File:30a Sammlung Eybl Großbritannien. Alfred Leete (1882–1933) Britons (Kitchener) wants you (Briten Kitchener braucht Euch). 1914 (Nachdruck), 74 x 50 cm. (Slg.Nr. 552).jpg|thumb|right|1914 "[[Lord Kitchener Wants You]]!" poster]]The first organized, large-scale [[propaganda]] campaigns were during World War I.<ref name="threethree"/> Germany created the German Information Bureau to create pamphlets, books and other communications that were intended to support the [[just war|justness of their cause]], to encourage voluntary recruitment, to demonize the enemy and persuade America to remain neutral in the conflict.<ref name=autogenerated3b>{{cite book|first=Ron|last=Smith|title=Public Relations: The Basics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5WxtAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA52|date=August 15, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-08967-2|page=52}}</ref><ref name="threethree">{{citation |last=Haste |first=Cate |title= Keep the Home Fires Burning: Propaganda in the First World War |location=London |year=1977}}</ref> In response to learning about Germany's propaganda, the British created a war propaganda agency called the [[Wellington House]] in September 1914.<ref name="oneone">{{citation |doi= 10.1017/S0018246X00008700|last1=Sanders|first1=M. L. |title= Wellington House and British propaganda during the First World War |work=The Historical Journal |volume=18 |issue=1 |date=1975 |pages=119–146 |jstor=2638471 |publisher= Cambridge University Press }}</ref><ref name="twotwo">{{citation |last1=Sanders |first1=M. L. |last2=Taylor| first2=Philip M. |title= British Propaganda During the First World War, 1914–18 |location=London |year=1982}}</ref> Atrocity stories, both real and alleged, were used to incite hatred for the enemy, especially after the "[[Rape of Belgium]]" in 1915.<ref>Laurence V. Moyer, ''Victory Must Be Ours: Germany in the Great War 1914–1918'', p 96 {{ISBN|0-7818-0370-5}}</ref><ref>{{citation |last1=Horne |first1=John |last2=Kramer |first2=Alan |title= German Atrocities, 1914: A History of Denial |location= London |year=2001}}</ref> France created a propaganda agency in 1914.<ref name="new">{{cite book |title= Selling the War |publisher= Orbis Publishing |first=Zbynek |last=Zeman |year=1978 |isbn= 0856133124}}</ref> Publicity in Australia led to a lift in the government's ban on military drafts.<ref name="Smith2013"/> Austria-Hungary used propaganda tactics to attack the credibility of Italy's leadership and its motives for war. Italy in-turn created the Padua Commission in 1918, which led Allied propaganda against Austria-Hungary.<ref>{{cite book |author=Cornwall, Mark |title= The Undermining of Austria-Hungary: The Battle for Hearts and Minds |date= September 2, 2000 |isbn=0-312-23151-2 |publisher= Palgrave Macmillan}}</ref>
One week after the United States declared war on Germany in 1917, US President [[Woodrow Wilson]] established the US propaganda agency, the [[Committee on Public Information]] (Creel Commission),<ref name="Ewen2008"/> as an alternative to demands for media censorship by the US army and navy.<ref name="twoway"/> The CPI spread positive messages to present an upbeat image about the war and denied fraudulent atrocities made up to incite anger for the enemy.<ref name = "Image">{{cite book| last =Creel| first= George| year= 1947| title =Rebel at Large: Recollections of Fifty Crowded Years| publisher= G.P. Putnam's Son's| location =NY}}</ref><ref name="illusion">{{cite book |first=Thomas |last=Fleming |title= The Illusion of Victory: America in World War I |location= New York |publisher= Basic Books |year= 2003}}</ref> The CPI recruited about 75,000 "[[Four Minute Men]]," volunteers who spoke about the war at social events for four minutes.<ref name = "War">{{cite book | last =Snow| first =Nancy | year =2003| title =Information War American Propaganda, Free Speech and Opinion Control since 9-11| publisher= Seven Stories Press |isbn =|page =52}}</ref>
As a result of World War I propaganda, there was a shift in PR theory from a focus on factual argumentation to one of emotional appeals and the psychology of the crowd.<ref name="Ewen2008"/> The term "propaganda" which was originally associated with religion and the church, became a more widely known concept.<ref name="twoway"/>
===World War II=== Propaganda did not develop a negative connotation until it was used in [[Nazi propaganda]] for World War II.<ref name="Welch 1993">{{cite book|last=Welch|first=David|title=The Third Reich: Politics and Propaganda|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=1993|isbn=0-203-93014-2}}</ref> Even though Germany's World War I propaganda was considered more advanced than that of other nations, [[Adolf Hitler]] said that propaganda had been under-utilized and claimed that superior British propaganda was the main reason for losing the war.<ref name="Welch 1993"/><ref name="Welch2000">{{cite book|first=David|last=Welch|title=Germany, Propaganda and Total War, 1914–1918: The Sins of Omission|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j_0od97nsRcC|year=2000|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-2798-7}}</ref><ref>Hitler, Adolf. ''Mein Kampf''. Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1999</ref> Nazi Germany created the [[Ministry of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda]] in March 1933, just after Nazis took power.<ref name="Potschka2012">{{cite book|first=Christian|last=Potschka|title=Towards a Market in Broadcasting: Communications Policy in the UK and Germany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lLceV6nvbFkC&pg=PT99|date=March 27, 2012|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-37020-3|page=99}}</ref> The Nazi party took editorial control over newspapers, created their own news organizations and established Nazi-controlled news organizations in conquered regions.<ref name="Welch 12">Welch, 12.</ref><ref name=Herzstein>{{cite book|last=Herzstein|first=Robert|title=The Nazis|publisher=Time-Life Books|location=Alexandria}}</ref> The Nazi party used posters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calvin.edu/academic/cas/gpa/posters2.htm |title=Nazi Posters: 1933–1945 |publisher=Calvin.edu |accessdate=February 9, 2013}}</ref> films,<ref>{{cite book| last = Romani| first = Cinzia| title = Tainted Goddesses: Female Film Stars of the Third Reich| year = 1992| isbn = 0-9627613-1-1 }}</ref> books<ref>{{cite book| author = George L. Mosse| title = Nazi Culture: intellectual, cultural and social life in the Third Reich| year = 1966| publisher = University of Wisconsin Press| isbn = 978-0-299-19304-1| page = 1 }}</ref> and public speakers<ref name="frostbite">{{cite web|url=http://www.calvin.edu/academic/cas/gpa/rsi27.htm |title=No Frostbite on the Eastern Front |publisher=Calvin.edu |date=February 21, 1942 |accessdate=February 9, 2013}}</ref> among other tactics.
According to historian [[Zbyněk Zeman]], broadcasting became the most important medium for propaganda throughout the war. Posters were also used domestically and leaflets were dropped behind enemy lines by air-ship.<ref name="new"/> In regions conquered by Germany, citizens could be punished by death for listening to foreign broadcasts. Britain had four organizations involved in propaganda and was methodical about understanding its audiences in different countries. US propaganda focused on fighting for freedom and the connection between war efforts and industrial production. Soviet posters also focused on industrial production.<ref name="new"/>
In countries where citizens are subordinate to the government, aggressive propaganda campaigns continued during peace-time, while liberal democratic nations primarily use propaganda techniques to support war efforts.<ref name="new"/>
==Professional development== According to historian Eric Goldman, by the 1940s public relations was being taught at universities and was a professional occupation relied on in a similar way as lawyers and doctors. However, it failed to obtain complete recognition as a profession due in part to a history of deceit.<ref name="twoway"/> Author Marvin Olasky said in 1987 that the reputation of the profession was getting worse,<ref name="latest">{{cite book | last =Olasky | first =Marvin | authorlink = | title =Corporate Public Relations: A New Historical Perspective | publisher =Lawrence Erlbaum Associates | year =1987 | isbn =0-8058-0052-2}}</ref> while Robert L. Heath from the [[University of Houston]] said in 1991 that it was progressing toward "true professional status."<ref name="Heath1991">{{cite journal|last1=Heath|first1=Robert L.|title=Public relations research and education: Agendas for the 1990s|journal=Public Relations Review|volume=17|issue=2|year=1991|pages=185–194|issn=0363-8111|doi=10.1016/0363-8111(91)90055-P}}</ref> Academic J. A. R. Pimlott said it had achieved "quasi-professionalism."<ref name="HeathToth2009">{{cite book|author1=Robert L. Heath|author2=Elizabeth L. Toth|author3=Damion Waymer|title=Rhetorical and Critical Approaches to Public Relations II|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QaDmVGkq9NMC&pg=PA98|accessdate=July 27, 2013|date=February 18, 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-203-87492-9|page=98}}</ref> Heath said despite the field's newfound professionalism and ethics, its reputation was still effected by a history of exploitive behavior.<ref name="Heath2006"/>
The number of media outlets increased and PR talent from wartime propaganda entered the private sector.<ref name="Watson2012"/><ref name="mcgraw">{{citation|title=Public Relations: The Profession and the Practice|url=http://highered.mcgraw-hill.com/sites/dl/free/0073512052/930653/Chapter_2.pdf|publisher=McGraw Hill|accessdate=August 6, 2014|first1=Dan|last1=Lattimore|first2=Otis|last2=Baskin|first3=Suzette|last3=Heiman|first4=Elizabeth|last4=Toth|first5=James|last5=Van Leuven}}</ref> The practice of public relations became ubiquitous to reach political, activist and corporate objectives. The development of the press into a more real-time media also led to heightened scrutiny of public relations activities and those they represent. For example, [[Richard Nixon]] was criticized for "doubletalk" and "stonewalling" in his PR office's responses to the [[Watergate scandal]].<ref name="managementt">{{cite book|last=Crable|first=Richard|author2=Steven Vibbert|title=Public Relations as Communication Management|publisher=Bellwether Press|year=1986|isbn=0-8087-4878-5}}</ref>
Trade associations were formed first in the U.S. in 1947 with the [[Public Relations Society of America]] (PRSA), followed by the Institute of Public Relations (now the [[Chartered Institute of Public Relations]]) in London in 1948. Similar trade associations were created in Australia, Europe, South Africa, Italy and Singapore. The International Association of Public Relations was founded in 1955.<ref name="Heath2006"/><ref name="autogenerated53"/> The Institute for Public Relations held its first conference in 1949 and that same year the first British book on PR, "Public Relations and publicity" was published by J.H. Brebner.<ref>{{citation|title=The evolution of evaluation|first=Tom|last=Watson|url=http://eprints.bournemouth.ac.uk/19076/1/Watson_%282011%29_The_evolution_of_evaluation_%28IHPRC%29.pdf|publisher=Bournemouth University|accessdate=March 28, 2014}}</ref> The [[International Association of Business Communicators]] was founded in 1970.<ref name="mcgraw"/> Betsy Ann Plank is called "the first lady of public relations" for becoming the first female president of the PRSA in 1973.<ref name="mcgraw"/>
Two of today's largest PR firms, [[Edelman]] and [[Burson-Marsteller]], were founded in 1952 and 1953 respectively.<ref name="SrirameshVercic2012"/> [[Daniel Edelman]] created the first media tour<ref name="SrirameshVercic2012"/> in the 1950s by touring the country with "the Toni Twins," where one had used a professional salon and the other had used Toni's home-care products.<ref>{{cite news|first=Stephen|last=Miller|title=Public-Relations Pioneer Began with 'Toni Twins' Stunt|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324235104578244253082298248|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=January 15, 2013|accessdate=July 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Dan Edelman, 1920–2013|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-01-16/news/ct-met-edelman-obit-0116-20130116_1_largest-pr-firm-richard-edelman-chicago-firm|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=January 16, 2013|first=Robert|last=Channick|accessdate=July 25, 2013}}</ref> It was also during this period that trade magazines like ''[[PR Week]]'', ''Ragans'' and ''PRNews'' were founded.<ref name="mcgraw"/> John Hill, founder of [[Hill & Knowlton]], is known as the first international PR pioneer.<ref name="SrirameshVercic2012"/> Hill & Knowlton was the first major U.S. firm to create a strong international network in the 1960s and 1970s.<ref name="MorrisGoldsworthy2011">{{cite book|author1=Trevor Morris|author2=Simon Goldsworthy|title=PR Today: The Authoritative Guide to Public Relations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YAWREYOZYhQC&pg=PA38|accessdate=July 25, 2013|date=November 23, 2011|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-24009-4|page=38}}</ref> Both Edelman and Burson-Marsteller followed Hill & Knowlton by establishing operations in London in the 1960s and all three began competing internationally in Asia, Europe and other regions.<ref name="SrirameshVercic2012"/> Jacques Coup de Frejac was influential in persuading U.S. and UK companies to also extend their PR efforts into the French market and for convincing French businesses to engage in PR activities.<ref name="SrirameshVercic2012"/> In the early 2000s, PR in Latin America began developing at a pace "on par with industrialized nations."<ref name="FreitagStokes2008">{{cite book|author1=Alan R. Freitag|author2=Ashli Quesinberry Stokes|title=Global Public Relations: Spanning Borders, Spanning Cultures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9Q2cGBDD60C&pg=PA240|accessdate=July 25, 2013|date= December 22, 2008|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-203-89018-9|page=240}}</ref>
According to ''The Global Public Relations Handbook'', public relations evolved from a series of "press agents or publicists" to a manner of theory and practice in the 1980s.<ref name="SrirameshVercic2012">{{cite book|author1=Krishnamurthy Sriramesh|author2=Dejan Vercic|title=The Global Public Relations Handbook, Revised Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VOT7RlW1CzoC&pg=PT994|accessdate=July 25, 2013|date=September 10, 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-84554-4|page=994}}</ref> Research was published in academic journals like ''Public Relations Review'' and the ''Journal of Public Relations Research''. This led to an industry consensus to categorize PR work into a four-step process: research, planning, communication and action.<ref name="mcgraw"/>
==Social and digital== During the 1990s specialties for communicating to certain audiences and within certain market segments emerged, such as investor relations or technology PR.<ref name="mcgraw"/> New internet technology and social media websites effected PR strategies and tactics.<ref name="mcgraw"/> In April 1999, four managers from [[IBM]], [[Sun Microsystems]], [[National Public Radio]] and [[Linux Journal]] created "[[The Cluetrain Manifesto]]." The Manifesto established 95 theses about the way social media and internet technologies were going to change business. It concluded that markets had become "smarter and faster than most companies," because stakeholders were getting information from each other.<ref>{{citation|publisher=Medill Department of Integrated Communications|first=Randy|last=Hlavac|last2=Schaefer|first2=Mark |title=The Social Media Revolution as Theorized by "The Cluetrain Manifesto"|url=http://jimc.medill.northwestern.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/9/2014/02/archives/2013/JIMC_Current_Issue_2013_Article_5.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Weinberg2009">{{cite book|first=Tamar|last=Weinberg|title=The New Community Rules: Marketing on the Social Web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wfk_HzC7bS8C&pg=PA63|date=July 1, 2009|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-7928-5|page=63}}</ref> The Manifesto "created a storm" with strong detractors and supporters.<ref name="Sheldrake2011">{{cite book|first=Philip|last=Sheldrake|title=The Business of Influence: Reframing Marketing and PR for the Digital Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t8xeQR6qatoC|date=May 4, 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-119-97830-5}}</ref> That same year, [[Seth Godin]] published a book on [[permission marketing]], which advocated against advertising and in favor of marketing that is useful and educational.<ref name="Sheldrake2011"/> While initially controversial, by 2006 it became commonly accepted that social media had an important role in public relations.<ref name="Sheldrake2011"/>
Press releases, which were mostly unchanged for more than a century, began to integrate digital features. [[BusinessWire]] introduced the "Smart News Release," which incorporated audio, video and images, in 1997. This was followed by the MultiVu multimedia release from [[PRNewswire]] in 2001.<ref name="brian">{{cite news|first=Brian|last=Solis|title=Reviving the Traditional Press Release|url=http://www.briansolis.com/2009/05/reviving-traditional-press-release/|publisher=Brian Solis|date=May 18, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> The Social Media Release was created by Todd Defren from [[Shift Communications]] in 2006<ref>{{cite news|title=BeB PR: New uses for press releases|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1626924/b2b-pr-new-uses-for-press-releases|newspaper=Fast Company|first=Wendy|last=Marx|date=April 25, 2010|accessdate=July 25, 2013}}</ref> in response to a blog written by journalist and blogger Tom Foremski titled "Die! Press release! Die! Die! Die!"<ref>{{cite news|title=The Social Press Release: Multimedia, Two-Way, Direct to the public|url=https://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2008/04/the-social-press-release-multimedia-two-way-direct-to-the-public100|date=April 9, 2008|first=Mark|last=Glaser|accessdate=July 25, 2013|publisher=MediaShift}}</ref> Incorporating digital and social features became a norm among wire services, and companies started routinely making company announcements on their corporate blog.<ref name="brian"/>
According to ''The New York Times'', corporate communications shifted from a monologue to two-way conversational communications<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|first=Stuart|last=Elliott|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/21/business/media/redefining-public-relations-in-the-age-of-social-media.html?_r=0|accessdate=July 29, 2013|title=Redefining Public Relations in the Age of Social Media|date=November 20, 2011}}</ref> and new media also made it "easier for consumers to learn about the mix-ups and blunders" of PR.<ref name="nyt"/> For example, after the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|''Deepwater Horizon'' oil spill]], [[British Petroleum|BP]] tried to deflect blame to other parties, claim the spill was not as significant as it was and focused on the science, while human interest stories related to the damage were emerging.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2010/06/10/10greenwire-bps-pr-blunders-mirror-exxons-appear-destined-98819.html?pagewanted=3|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 10, 2010|accessdate=July 29, 2013|first=Anne|last=Mulkern|title=BP's PR Blunders Mirror Exxon's, Appear Destined for Record Book }}</ref> In 2011, Facebook tried to covertly spread privacy concerns about competitor Google's Social Circles.<ref>{{cite news|title=Facebook, Foe of Anonymity, is Forced to Explain a Secret|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 13, 2011|first=Miguel|last=Helft|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/14/technology/14facebook.html|accessdate=July 29, 2013}}</ref> [[Chapstick]] created a communications crisis after allegedly, repeatedly deleting negative comments on its Facebook page.<ref>{{cite news|title=ChapStick Gets Itself in a Social Media Death Spiral|date=October 26, 2011|first=Tim|last=Nudd|url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/chapstick-gets-itself-social-media-death-spiral-136097|newspaper=AdWeek|accessdate=July 29, 2013}}</ref> During the [[Iraq War]], it was exposed that the US created false radio personalities to spread pro-American information and paid Iraqi newspapers to write articles written by American troops.<ref name="Schleifer, Ron 2005">{{Citation|last=Schleifer|first=Ron|title=Reconstructing Iraq: Winning the Propaganda War in Iraq|newspaper=Middle East Quarterly|year=2005}}</ref><ref name="ShahAnup">{{citation|last=Shah|first=Anup|title=Iraq War Media Reporting, Journalism and Propaganda|date=August 1, 2007|accessdate=May 12, 2009|url=http://www.globalissues.org/article/461/media-reporting-journalism-and-propaganda}}</ref>

'''Ilian Vassilev''' ({{lang-bg|Илиян Василев}}) (born July 7, 1956) is a Bulgarian [[diplomat]], a Bulgarian writer, and political [[Blogger (person)|blogger]]. He was President of the Bulgarian Foreign Investment Agency from 1997 to 2000, the [[Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary]] of the [[Republic of Bulgaria]] to the [[Russian Federation]] from 2000 to 2006,<ref>{{cite web | title = Bulgarian-Russian International Relations | publisher = [[About Bulgaria (In Russian)]] | url = http://www.aboutbulgaria.biz/bulgaria/foreign_affairs/bulgaria_russia/ | accessdate = 2014-06-23|language=ru}}</ref> following which he became Chairman of [[Deloitte]] in Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sbs-bg.org/author/ilian-vassilev/ |title=Ilian Vassilev Profile |publisher=Sofia Business School |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> At present he is Managing Partner of his own consulting company Innovative Energy Solutions. He is Chairman of the Reform Union Club (RUC) and Honorary Chair of the Bulgarian Economic Forum since its Foundation in 1997. Ilian Vassilev also coordinates the Sofia Business School, a joint undertaking of the RUC and the New Bulgarian University. He has served as advisor on [[energy]] related matters to succeeding Bulgarian governments and appears as a regular [[energy security]] commentator for western news outlets, including the Financial Times,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/4a62bd54-4a45-11dd-891a-000077b07658,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F4a62bd54-4a45-11dd-891a-000077b07658.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&siteedition=uk&_i_referer= |title=Guest column: Location could be a golden ticket |publisher=The Financial Times |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> Reuters,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINL5E8KDB3020120913 |title=Bulgaria may seek South Stream bargain with Russia |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/idvassilev |title=Ilian Vassilev (idvassilev) on Twitter |publisher=Twitter |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Energy security activism== Since leaving Deloitte in 2011 to found his own [[management consulting]] company, Innovative Energy Solutions,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://innoenergy.biz/about.html |title=Ilian Vassilev |publisher=Innovative Energy Solutions |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> Vassilev has been an outspoken [[energy security]] activist,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bulenergyforum.org/energy-blog/publications/call-for-participation-for-international-nuclear-conference/ |title=International Nuclear Conference |publisher=Bulgarian Energy and Mining Forum |accessdate=June 23, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140623112832/http://bulenergyforum.org/energy-blog/publications/call-for-participation-for-international-nuclear-conference/ |archivedate=June 23, 2014 |df= }}</ref> supporting the development of [[shale gas]] fields in Bulgaria,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2014/06/11/chevrons-bulgaria-pull-out-a-blow-for-energy-security/?Authorised=false |title=Chevron's Bulgaria pull-out a blow for energy |publisher=The Financial Times |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> construction of the [[Nabucco pipeline]] project,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.focus-fen.net/opinion/0000/00/00/3299/ |title=Nabucco West: A Fateful Choice for Bulgaria |publisher=The Focus Information Agency |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> and commentator regarding the viability of the Belene NPP,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://3e-news.net/getatt.php?filename=oo_o_22373.pdf |title=The Belene NPP Project - Mission Impossible? |publisher=The Center for Balkan and Blacksea Studies |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref> and the [[South Stream]] project.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/a3fb2954-d11d-11e3-9f90-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2Fa3fb2954-d11d-11e3-9f90-00144feabdc0.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&siteedition=uk&_i_referer= |title=Russia's South Stream Gas Pipeline to Europe Divides EU |publisher=The Financial Times |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Political and social activism== Ilian Vassilev has built a reputation as a critic of corruption. He has been vocal about the fact that Bulgaria's Prosecution acts like a "baseball bat" and attacks those who criticize the status quo.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://frognews.bg/politika/iliian-vasilev-peevskite-medii-shte-blokirat-obvineniia-traikov-izborite.html|title=Илиян Василев: Пеевските медии ще блокират обвинения Трайков за изборите|publisher=frognews.bg|date= 2 January 2017|access-date=28 November 2017}}</ref> He has expressed worries that Bulgaria's General Prosecutor [[Sotir Tsatsarov]] continuously exceeds his powers under Bulgaria's Constitution and acts like a hub spreading Russian influence in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://clubz.bg/58507-iliqn_vasilev_cacarov_e_hyb_za_distribuciq_na_rusko_vliqnie|title=Илиян Василев: Цацаров е хъб за дистрибуция на руско влияние|publisher=clubz.bg|date= 19 September 2017|access-date=29 November 2017}}</ref> Ilian Vassilev has also raised concern about Bulgaria's practices of corporate-raiding and political repressions. In a commentary on his popular blog, he famously said: "You are an owner until [[Boyko Borisov|Borisov]] and [[Delyan Peevski|Peevski]] decide so."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://frognews.bg/novini/iliian-vasilev-borisov-peevski-shtom-reshat-vzemat-sobstvenostta.html|title=Илиян Василев: Собственик си, докато Пеевски и Борисов решат|publisher=frognews.bg|date= 8 October 2017|access-date=29 November 2017}}</ref> Recently, he underscored that the unexpected dismissal of an established journalist was an example of the authoritarian tendencies in Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://offnews.bg/medii/svaliha-ot-efir-predavaneto-na-liuba-kulezich-video-669921.html|title=Свалиха от ефир предаването на Люба Кулезич |publisher=offnews.bg|date= 24 November 2017|access-date=29 November 2017}}</ref>
